loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Mrs. Nimfa M. wishes to apply for a loan from ASHI amounting to Php7,000. This loan would be her source of capital to put up her sari-sari store (mini variety store). At the same time, Nimfa would spend a small portion of her loan for her farm inputs. Rice she will be harvesting, will be sold in her own store.

Out of the income her business could generate, Nimfa plans to save in order to achieve her dream of building a house that would secure her and her only child against any kind of calamity, sickness, and any forms of harm. Nimfa wishes that someday, there will be no more raindrops falling into their house.

Since Nimfa's husband died, she is the one who stood as a father and mother to her only child, Jenilyn M.. Her courage and perseverance were tested several times already yet she remained determined for her child. Furthermore, she was able to send her daughter to school up to college and have her graduate as a teacher. However, because of the country's problem with employment generation, Nimfa's daughter could not practice her expertise and could not get employed. Therefore, she can't help her mother augment their income for their everyday expenses.  

Through Nimfa's membership in ASHI and the loan she availed, she and her daughter were given a chance to get employed by putting up their own business. Nimfa and her daughter had to work hard to achieve their dreams and could experience a better life.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store

texts.en:
Sevda Group has seven members, of which Sevda A. N. is the leader. The group is requesting a loan of $US 1500 to improve their following businesses.

Sevda wants a loan for her embroidery business. Sakaba wants to take assist her husband with his car parts shop. Mallei wants to help her son with his vegetables and fruits shop. Zenat wants a loan for the tailoring business. Shmen wants to assist her son with his ice cream shop. Qais also wants to improve his ice cream business. Finally, Amal wants to expand his taxi business. They are thankful to kiva lenders for their worldwide support.

loans.use: To expand businesses

loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a 46-year-old businesswoman blessed with four children who are all going to school. She owns and operates a beauty salon, which she started two years ago. In order to meet her customers’ demands, she is requesting a loan of $2,500 so that she can buy work materials such as combs, creams, gels and gloves, amongst other things. 

Among her goals are letting her children continue their studies so that they can achieve a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy work materials such as combs, creams, gels and gloves

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen M. is a 68-year-old single woman who lives with 53-year-old Susan Sanchez. Susan is Carmen's business partner and they sell cooked food, rice, and other common commodities for the convenience of their neighbors. They chose this kind of business considering the large distance of their residence from the main municipality.

The business has been run since she received her first loan from ASHI amounting to Php 5,000. Now, Carmen wishes to apply for a loan from ASHI amounting to Php 7,000 to be used in the same kind of business. Given a chance to receive the bigger loan, the volume of commodities she will sell will be increased and she can help many people from their village have access to commodities with less effort and time consumed.

Despite her age, Carmen wants to maximize her remaining strength and capacity in her business so as to have savings. In this way, she can obtain the security of tenure she wishes for herself when she grows very old. As a single, old woman, she believes that there will be nobody to take care of her nor shelter her when she becomes very old unless she has money. 

Carmen, though, is very positive that she will be able to manage her business well and have it grow.

loans.use: To buy rice, gasoline and vinegar to sell

loans.name: Sol

texts.en: Sol T. is from the village of Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 40 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Sol owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Sol joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Sol is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 7th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Merlyn R. is a second loanee of ASHI. Her first loan was Php 5,000 and now she is applying for a Php 10,000 loan to be used primarily in her livestock-raising and farming business. Since Merlyn had shown very good performance during her first loan, she is qualified to obtain the said amount. There is no doubt she will perform very well again because her husband, Eduardo, has been supporting her endeavor for the future of their six children. They both believe that sending their children to school would require a lot of money. However, the couple still thinks that they can surmount this life's test if they are supported by ASHI.

Through the loan Merlyn has received and will be receiving further, her skill in farming and livestock raising, as well as her husband's, will be put to practice and will be enhanced even more. Therefore, they are pretty sure that they will make their business successful because this kind of business was their parents' source of income when they were both young.

Having capital to grow this kind of business, Merlyn and her husband hope that they will be able to send their children to school until they graduate from college in order for them to have a different kind of living in the future. They know how hard it is being farmers. Small profit because of the low demand during harvest, and absence of a market can not compensate for the expensive farm inputs, plus the requirement of manual labor.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs for raising livestock

loans.name: Imad

texts.en: Imad is 36 years old, married, and has three children. He owns a small fruit and vegetable shop in the city of Hebron, Palestine. He is requesting a loan of $1,000 that he will use to purchase more fruits and vegetables. Imad and his family greatly appreciate the trust and support that you offer them. Today is the time to help.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa M. is from the village of Carmen, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 57 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Elisa owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily through orders (catering services). She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Elisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Elisa is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 5th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Carmen, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida M. is from the village of Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 56 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Aida owns and operates a business operating a specialized retail store, primarily selling vegetables in Cogon public market. She has been in this business for almost ten years. In 2008, Aida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Aida is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Baikingon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Hiathm

texts.en:
Hiathm is 36 years old, married, and has two children. He runs a blacksmith's shop where he makes wrought-iron gates, railings, and chairs.

Hiathm wants to expand his business in order to serve more customers. He wants to buy new machinery that would make him capable of diversifying his output; therefore, he is asking to borrow $2,200. 

With your help he will succeed.

loans.use: To buy new machinery

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
Rosie Z. wishes to sustain her only child's education until college. That is why she works hard to put up her own business through a loan she received from ASHI and with the support of her husband, Rey. Rosie and Rey think that, while their only child is still young (four years old) and they are both 43 years old and are still able, they have to have a sustainable source of income in order to save money for their child's future. 

With the loan she is applying for presently, amounting to Php 10,000, she wishes to buy necessary ingredients for her business baking and selling pastries and sweet delicacies. Given a chance to receive bigger loans from ASHI in future cycles, Rosie foresee her business growing and will be operating in other towns not just in her own.

loans.use: To buy necessary ingredients for her baking business

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda L. is from the town of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 59 years old, is married, and has eight adult children. Linda owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Linda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Linda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Issa

texts.en:
Issa is a 25-year-old single man. He live with his mother and father and he is responsible for their living expenses.

Issa has a butcher's shop.He provides the markets with meat and his family with food. Now Issa is requesting a loan of $1,500. Due to the determination of this micro-entrepreneur, the profitability of his business, and his experience, Issa is qualified to receive this loan. He is counting on your help – your support will really help him.

loans.use: To buy more meat to expand his business

loans.name: Janice

texts.en: Janice B. is from the town of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 24 years old, is separated from her spouse, and has two school-aged children. Janice owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily buying and selling dried fish and Avon products. Janice has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month She has frequent customers who buy her products. Janice serves as bread-winner to her family. She works hard for the future of her two children. In 2008, Janice joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Janice has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Janice is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Majed

texts.en:
Majed lives in the city of Hebron in Palestine. He is 39 years old, married, and has two children.

Majed owns a small shop that sells vegetables and fruit and this business is his family's source of income. Majed needs a loan in the amount of $1,000 to buy more kinds of goods so he can expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine J. is from the town of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old, is married and has six adult children. Christine owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily selling fish in Puerto public market. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Christine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family and to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Gerrilyn

texts.en: Gerrilyn J. is from the town of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. She is 36 years old, is married, and has seven infant children. Gerrilyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily selling fish in bulk in Puerto public market. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Gerrilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and to support the needs of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nadim

texts.en: Nadim is 25 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hebron, Palestine. He runs a small grocery store selling food. His store is well known in the neighborhood as he serves his customers well and works late hours. Currently he is seeking a loan of $2,000 to to buy more foodstuffs in order to improve his business. He sends his thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory to increase the variety of goods he offers

loans.name: Talal

texts.en: Talal is a 25-year-old single man who lives in the city of Hebron, Palestine. He sells fruits and vegetables and is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and has a good quality of merchandise. Now he needs a loan of $2,000 to buy more kinds of goods so that he can expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more kinds of goods

loans.name: Agua De La Vida Group

texts.es:
La asociación denominada “Agua De La Vida” forma parte de la familia de  Pro-Mujer hace diez años aproximadamente, pertenece al centro focal Los Andes, ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha  cuenta con doce miembros y  han demostrado ser un grupo organizado en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito y actividades internas.
La fundadora del grupo es Susi Díaz, ella formo este grupo con amigos  y familiares. Dentro el grupo la mayoría son casadas y con hijos, casi todos en edad escolar y también universitarios,  diversos son los negocios de este grupo, por ejemplo Verónica se dedica a la venta de ropa para bebes, Susi elabora y vende comida, Martha tienen una librería, Juan José es mecánico, Alejandro  ofrece servicio de Internet, Alicia vende CDs en ferias de la ciudad. Necesitan capital para realizar compras de mercadería al por mayor para mejorar sus ganancias y cumplir con las obligaciones que tienen con sus familias.
texts.en:
The association named “Life Water” has been part of the Pro-Mujer family for approximately ten years; it belongs to the main center Los Andes, located in the city of El Alto. Currently it includes twelve members and they have shown to be an organized group when it comes to their loan payments and internal activities. The founder of the group is Susi Díaz; she created this group with friends and family. Within the group the majority of the members are married women with children, almost all school aged and also university students. The group’s businesses are diverse, for example, Verónica dedicates herself to the sale of clothing for babies, Susi makes and sells food, Martha has a bookstore, Juan José is a mechanic, Alejandro offers Internet services, and Alicia sells CDs in markets in the city. They need capital to purchase wholesale merchandise to improve their earnings and fulfill their obligations to their families.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Maravilla Group

texts.es:
La asociación denominada “Maravilla” trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer hace siete años, se reúnen cada dos semanas en el centro focal Los andes, ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a la fecha  cuenta con doce miembros. Con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos realizan sus actividades de forma responsable.
Diferentes son las actividades de esta asociación, como ser la venta de abarrotes, venta  de ropa ligera, costura de ropa, sabanas y cortinas, venta de carne de res, víveres y otros . Desean ampliar sus ventas, para esto necesitan comprar mercadería o materia prima al por mayor, están seguros que  mejoraran  sus ganancias y puedan cubrir  los gastos que tienen en sus hogares.
texts.en:
The association named “Wonder” has worked with Pro-Mujer for the past 7 years; they get together every two weeks in the main center Los Andes, located in the city of El Alto. Currently the group consists of twelve members. With the help of their loan counselor they carry out their activities in a responsible manner. This association carries out different activities, such as, the sale of groceries, the sale of light clothing, sewing clothing, blankets, and curtains, the sale of meat, supplies, and others. They would like to expand their sales, and for that the need to purchase merchandise or basic materials wholesale. They are certain that they will improve their earnings and will be able to cover their household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise or basic materials.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Wiphala Group

texts.es:
La asociación comunal Wipala en un grupo de mujeres, que fueron conformadas hace seis meses atrás por la señora  Margarita rodrigues, quien actualmente es la presidenta, ella indica que por la necesidad de obtener ingresos se animo a formar un grupo y así poder acceder a un préstamo.
La mayoría de las integrantes tienen negocios pequeños como ser costura de deportivos, elaboración de masitas, tejidos y otros. Ellas destinaran el préstamo a la compra de tela, harina y lana (dependiendo del caso).
texts.en:
The Wiphala group is comprised of women who came together under the leadership of Margarita R., their current group president, six months ago. Margarita states that she decided to form this group and request a loan out of the need to earn a living.

Most of the group members have small businesses, such as a sporting apparel factory, making masitas (pastries), weaving, and other businesses. They will use this loan to purchase fabric, flour, and wool (depending on what type of business they have).

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw materials and supplies

loans.name: Nak

texts.en:
Nak S., 26 years old, lives with her family in the province of Pursat in Cambodia. She and her husband are rice farmers and they have two children who are students.

This couple wants to make additional profit by investing as pig breeders. They have had the skill of raising pigs for a long time but lacked the money to do so. Therefore, Nak S. is looking for a loan from Kiva in order to purchase a piglet to raise and to use the remainder of the loan to grow crops.

Nak S.'s husband is shown in the photo of their farmland.

loans.use: To purchase a piglet to raise

loans.name: Sun

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Mrs. Sun B., age 44, who lives in the Province of Pursat in Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. Since 1999, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living.

She is married with two children who are secondary students: the first child attends class 10 and the other attends class 8. Her husband helps her in raising pigs.

In order to earn extra income, Sun B. will be using the loan to buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more pig-feed and piglets to raise

loans.name: Levi

texts.en: Levi C. is from the village of Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 37 years old, is married, and has six school-aged children. Levi owns and operates a business buying and selling raw bananas, selling both to tourists and to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Levi joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Levi is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business by buying more bananas and therefore earning more, also. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family and for the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business by buying more bananas

location.town: Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Phouk

texts.en:
Phouk P. is 66 years old, a widower, and the father of four children: two are married and work selling grilled-meatballs from home, while the other two are single and work as office staff members for a casino club.

For over nineteen years, Phouk P. has had a job as a domestic carpenter, making beds, windows, chairs, tables, and other furniture. He has also been hired by people to produce furniture to decorate their houses. Phouk P. will be using the loan to buy wood and some equipment to support his carpentry business.

loans.use: To buy wood and some equipment to support his carpentry business

loans.name: Alia

texts.en:
Alia S. makes a living primarily from selling raw bananas and coconut fruits in her local community. She is 28 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. Alia has been in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Alia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Alia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Alia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to buy more bananas and coconut fruits. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support the education of her children and to supplement income for her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy bananas and coconuts

location.town: Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Mrs. Khun P. is 20 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. She has been blessed with a lovely young child who is still not in school. She and her husband are local rice cultivators. Besides the farming work, Khun P. raises a few sows for their piglets to sell, which is the main source of the family's income. Khun P. will take out a loan from Kiva's partner HKL in order to buy an extra sow to raise its offspring and to purchase a cart to make transportation easier during the approaching rice harvesting season.

loans.use: To buy an extra sow to raise its offspring

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mr. C., 27, is a person living in the capital of Phnom Penh. He is married to Meach Thavrom, 21, and they have two children who are still young and attend school. This young couple currently work in the garment industry and they both get specific salaries of $180 per month to manage their family’s living expenses.

This family is facing difficulty with transportation to work because their motorbike is often broken. Because of this obstacle, Mr. C. has decided to ask for a loan to replace his old motor. He proposes to use the remainder of the loan to decorate his old house.

loans.use: To replace his old motor

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna D., age 28, owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells bananas, coconuts and leafy vegetables. Lorna is separated from her spouse and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City. Her main source of income comes primarily from selling a variety of different agricultural products in her local community. Lorna has been in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en: C. Sophea, 30, is married and lives with her only child and her husband. The family is dependent totally on her husband, Chheoun Seang, who is collecting stones from the mountains for construction building. Her husband has been involved in this business for four years and earns $2 per day. Hence, to maintain a good standard of living, she is requesting a loan of $1000 to further her husband’s business of transporting the stones for selling. She will use the loan to buy a new car engine and replace the old one. By doing this, she hopes to earn more income from her husband's current job.

loans.use: To buy a new car engine

loans.name: Chhit's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is for four borrowers who hope to use the loan for different purposes. Chhit S., 53, has been selected to be the leader by the other members. She is a widowed woman who has given birth to five children: three are single and the others are married and live independently. She stays at home to take care of her children and maintain a daily routine. The entire family’s daily expenses are covered by her four employed children: two daughters are garment workers, while her two sons work as blacksmiths in the village. Chhit S.’s children have been facing difficulty with transportation for a long time. They always hire taxis to get to work. To cut down on the cost of transportation, Chhit S. is applying for a loan to purchase a motor for her children to ride to work.

The other members who have joined this loan are: Mr. C. is a staff member for a gasoline station, seeking a loan to buy a motor for driving to work. Mrs. S., 48, sells some vegetables in the market. She is asking for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. Mr. P. is a community consultant adviser, requesting a loan to purchase grocery items for his wife to sell. He was not available for the photo so his wife is in the photo instead.

loans.use: To purchase a motor

loans.name: Hishigjargal

texts.en: Hishigjargal D. lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter, 8 years old, is a 2nd grade student in a local high school. Her youngest daughter is just 1 year old and stays home. Khishigjargal runs a small public bathhouse for locals. These bath houses are quite common in places like Arhangai province since many of the local people live in traditional tents and do not have any access to hot water. They visit here once in a while and take hot showers for sanitary purposes. Since there are only two bathhouses in the town, many locals often come in her bathhouse and take hot showers. Her husband helps in her business and takes care of heating the bathhouse.  She requests a loan to purchase coal for heating her bathhouse.

loans.use: To buy coal to heat bathhouse.

loans.name: Than

texts.en: M. Than, 29, runs a grocery store in her village. She makes a daily profit of $1 per day. She lives with her husband and her three children who are all school aged. Her husband, 28, buys cows at the nearby villages and resells them for a small profitable price. Hence, she has made a decision to take a loan of $800 from KIVA to expand her husband’s business by buying more cows to resell. If she succeeds in her business plan, she will be able to afford for all of her children to study at a university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To purchase more cows to sell.

loans.name: Sa Beoun

texts.en: M. Sa Beoun, 38, is a worker whose job is splitting stone into pieces for construction buildings and infrastructure. She and her husband can earn $3 per day. She and her husband have three children. One of her children is a student and the rest are working, like their parents. She wants to take a $500 loan from KIVA. This loan would be used to buy a type of equipment that will enable her family members to split the stone faster and more easily into pieces to sell and make a good income. This loan will allow the family to generate more income.

loans.use: To buy stone-splitting equipment.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie P., age 24, makes a living primarily from buying raw bananas, coconut fruits and other agricultural products from neighboring village and selling to the local community. Melanie is married and has two small children. They are from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City. Melanie has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to buy more products to sell. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a retail business

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Phul

texts.en: C. Phul, 29, is married and stays at home to look after her two school-aged children. Her husband has been a motor-taxi driver for 8 years with a daily income of $2. Phul also takes care of her aged mother. After facing the great hardship of using an old motorbike in the business for a long time, Phul has decided to take a loan from KIVA of $700 to buy a new motorbike for her husband’s business. She hopes all of her children will have a chance to study at a good university when they finish high school.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Doem

texts.en: The person who wears the red-shirt in the photo is L., age 40. She lives in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She has built a small salon shop in front of her house where she sells a few ladies’ beauty salon products to neighbors in the village. She generates an average of $4 profit a day to feed her family. She has three children who are of school age. The other income for the family comes from her husband’s work, driving a truck for a small firm. L. runs her business very well and she hopes to better meet her customer's requirements by using a loan from Kiva to expand the selection of beauty salon items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of beauty salon products to sell.

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en: Byambasuren T. lives with her husband and her 8-year-old daughter in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her daughter is a student in a local secondary school. Byambasuren has a small business in cell phone accessories. She rents a small stall in the local market and sells various cell phone accessories. She started her cell phone accessories business with her husband in 2007. Since the beginning, her business has done well; her business capital has increased from 100,000 MNT to 600,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). In the future, she would like expand her business by adding a small section for cell phone repair. She sees a lucrative business in cell phone repairs. She requests a loan to purchase more cell phone accessories for her business.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone accessories for her business.

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mr. Mai R., 37, and his wife, Mrs. Sarum Tun, 44, have been married since 1985. They have five children: three sons (all of whom are construction workers), two daughters (one is in school and another daughter is still young). The family lives along National Road Number one, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Mai has been a construction worker for over 20 years. He works in his village and in the nearby district. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. He hopes to support his daughters’ further education. Mai’s materials and tools are old and some parts break down; it upsets his business because he cannot work smoothly. The construction work is the main source of income for the family. So, he is requesting his first loan of $500 to purchase new construction materials and tools to continue the business.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials and tools for his business.

loans.name: Bujinlham

texts.en: Bujinlham G. is 51 years old and lives with her husband in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two sons have already grown up and live with their own families. Bujinlham has a small business retailing dairy products. She rents a small stall in the local food market and sells dairy products such as milk, cheese and other milk products. Since the start in 2003, her business has done well; her business capital has increased from 500,000 MNT to 2,500,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). Her husband also helps in her business with purchasing and collecting dairy products from the wholesale market. In the future, she hopes to expand her business by adding more diverse products to her stall. With the profit, together with her husband, she has started building a house on the plot of land that they own. They are planning to finish building their house before year-end. She requests a loan to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.use: To buy more dairy products to increase her business inventory.

loans.name: Somnang

texts.en:
Mrs. Somnang, 34, and her husband, Mr. Som-un Eang, 43, live along national road number one, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1998 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two of the children attend school and the other one is still young. 

Somnang has been selling clothes for two years. She buys the clothes from Olympic market located in Phnom Penh for resale in her village. Mr. Som-un Eang has been driving a motor taxi for eleven years. Besides driving motor taxi, he also grows rice. He wants to drive a Tuk Tuk taxi as it would be better for him to earn enough income to support his family. Therefore, Somnang is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to purchase a trailer for her husband to drive as Tuk Tuk taxi and to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer for her husband to drive as Tuk Tuk taxi and to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap C., age 37, and her husband, Mr. Saphai Morm, age 42, have been married since 1991. They have five children, four sons and one daughter. Four of their children are studying in a local school, and the youngest one stays at home. Sopheap and her family live along National Road Number one, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sopheap has been weaving cotton scarves since 1985. It’s a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products in Olympic market, located in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a teacher. She has set up three looms under her house. Sopheap is able to only use one loom because she doesn’t have enough capital to purchase cotton threads. Now Sopheap is requesting second loan of $1,000 in order to purchase cotton thread materials for her three looms.

loans.use: To purchase cotton threads for her scarf weaving business.

loans.name: Oeurn

texts.en: Oeurn C., 33, has been selling groceries in front of her house for nine years. She sells items such as cooking ingredients, plastic goods, canned food, and sweets for kids. She earns around $3 income per day. As another income source, her husband raises pigs as well as distills white wine from their home. This couple has a teenage child who attends school and is still under their care. Oeurn C. is requesting a loan to purchase additional piglets to breed. With the remainder of the loan she will buy more grocery items to sell.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets to breed.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla S., 33, and her husband, Mr. Sokha Ung, 39, live along national road number one about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have three children: two sons and one daughter. The eldest son is a garment factory worker.

Phalla has been selling groceries for four months. She buys grocery items from Korky market about 2 kilometers from her village for resale at her shop, which is in front of her house. She is able to get a gross income of about $2.50 per day. Besides selling groceries, Phalla is also a farmer. Her husband has been a construction worker for 15 years. 

She is requesting her first loan of $700 in order to purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son to drive to work.

loans.name: Salvador

texts.en:
Salvador H. is from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 51 years old. Salvador is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Salvador owns & operates a specialized retail store. He is also into a buying and selling business where he buys agricultural products such as banana, coconut and corn and sells them to the community. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling banana, corn and copra products to the local community. He is also engaged in traditional gold mining. Salvador has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Salvador joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salvador has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell in his mini variety store and additional working capital on his buy and sell business. Salvador is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business and for the educational needs of his children. Part of the loan also will be used to partly renovate his house. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Salvador from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the educational needs of his children and to supplement the income of his family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand his business and renovate his house

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Touni

texts.en: Mrs. S. R. is 29 years old. She stays at home to take care of her two children and is responsible for the daily routine. She currently relies on income from her husband's taxi business and uses this income to manage the entire family's daily food. Her husband owns a car to provide a taxi service. S. R.'s husband can't generate as much profit as before because their old taxi is not attractive. Because of this bad condition, S. R. is applying for a $1200 loan to add to her savings to replace their existing taxi. She also proposes to run a suitable business as a fake jewelry seller in the market using some of this loan.

loans.use: To replace their existing taxi

loans.name: Wilfreda

texts.en:
Wilfreda M. is from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 43 years old. Wilfreda is widowed and has four adult children. To make a living, Wilfreda owns & operates a business where she sells bananas and vegetables. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling bananas and vegetables in the local community. Wilfreda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Wilfreda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilfreda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Wilfreda is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Wilfreda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Nafeesa Raees Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Shahida baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. 
Musarat baji and Naziran baji each want a loan to buy mason tools. 

Nafeesa baji is the wife of R. A. who has lived in Lahore, Pakistan for the last 12 years. Her husband runs a decorative embroidery business. He sells embroidered dresses to the cloth shops and buys from the famous markets of Lahore “Ichra and Shahalmi”. Nafeesa baji herself has a dairy business. She grows the animals (goats) and then sells their milk to the milk shops and earns income. With the income, she renovated her house. She is applying for a loan to buy embroidered dresses to grow her husband’s business.  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy embroidered dresses to sell

loans.name: Samer

texts.en:
Samer is 21 years old. He is a small entrepreneur who sells various kinds of foodstuffs such as cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, macaroni, and many others in his grocery store, which he built one year ago. 

Today Samer is requesting a loan of $1000 to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur.

Samer is very grateful to everyone who helps him to achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: Increase his stock

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita Q. is from the village of Batinay, Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 50 years old. Angelita is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Angelita owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling pre-packed snack foods, dairy products and daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Angelita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Angelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Angelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

location.town: Batinay, Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Or

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase refrigerator for her shop.

loans.name: Hamidan Riaz Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji wants a loan to buy cigarettes to sell.

Azra baji and Allah rakhi baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

Farzana baji wants a loan to pay off the installments of a tractor.

Hamidan baji is a very hardworking and responsible lady. She gets up early in the morning and prepares breakfast for her family. Then she readies her children for school and cleans the whole house. She performs her duties very efficiently. She is also the group leader of these above mentioned ladies. Her members respect her a lot because of her good nature.

Her husband’s name is R. A. and he runs a business making and selling plastic brushes. His brushes are used to clean washrooms. He sells the brushes to the market and earns income. Hamidan baji helps him by making the plastic brushes. She is applying for a loan to buy plastic beans and shapes for her husband’s plastic-brush business.

loans.use: To buy material for making plastic brushes

loans.name: Anwar Muhammad Noor Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji wants a loan to buy repairing tools for her bicycle-repairing business.

Razia baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (colored thread, clothes and beads) for her decorative-embroidery business.

Naseem baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy a lathe. 

Anwar baji belongs to a conservative family. Her society was against educating girls and her parents were forced to conform. She feels being deprived of knowledge a blessing but she decided that this shouldn’t happen to her children. She has two children: one son and one daughter. Her children are very happy with her. Anwar baji operates a business sewing clothes to pay her children’s school fees.

Anwar baji married M. N. who is a salesman and sells bakery items. She is applying for a loan to buy bakery items (biscuits & chips) wholesale so that her husband is able to sell them to the grocery shops and increase his profit.

loans.use: To buy bakery items wholesale to sell

loans.name: Usuf

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
 Юсуф Ниёзов родился в 1960 году. По специальности он преподователь, преподает урок арифметики в местной школе. Юсуф живет вместе со своей семьей. Женой Рахимой и 3 детьми.Жена Юсуфа домохозяйка, занимается воспитанием детей.
Сыновья Юсуфа уже имеют свои собственные семья. Старший сын плотник, он каждый месяц зарабатывает 500 сомони, а младший занимается ремонтом автобусов, и зарабатывает в месяц 350 сомони. Дочка Юсуфа еще маленькая, она учится в школе.
Так как заработная плата у преподователя в нашей стране очень низкая, Юсуф занимается еще и животноводством. В этом деле ему помогают жена, и невестки.Первый раз когда наш клиент получил кредит у него было 7 голов крупнорогатого скота, на сегодняшний день их уже 9 голов. Он хочет получить  кредит во второй раз, для того чтобы откормить свой скот и перепродать его на рынке.
Планиреут увеличть колличество своего скота до 11 голов.
texts.en:
Usuf N. was born in 1960. He is an arithmetic teacher at a local school. Usuf lives with his family – wife Rahima and their 3 children. Usuf’s wife is a homemaker, raising children. Usuf’s sons already have their own families. His oldest son is carpenter, making 500 somoni every month. The younger son is a bus mechanic, making 350 somoni per month. Usuf’s daughter is still very young and goes to school. Because a teacher’s salary is very low in this country, Usuf is also involved in animal husbandry. His wife and daughters-in-law help him with the business. When Usuf first obtained a loan, he had 7 heads of livestock and has 9 today. He wants to obtain this second loan in order to feed his livestock and resell it at a market. He plans to increase his livestock quantity to 11 heads.

MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”. “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Feeding and sale of cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase poultry-feed and feeding equipment

loans.name: Allah Rakhi Muhammad Aslam Group

texts.en:
Zahida baji wants a loan to buy tea to sell.

Majeedan baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business.

Shamim baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (colored thread, beads and clothes) for her decorative-embroidery business.

Kishwar baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.

Allah rakhi baji is the group leader of these above mentioned ladies. These all are very hardworking ladies. They run their own businesses to support their families.

Allah rakhi baji runs her decorative-embroidery business. She takes orders from her neighbors and from the clothes shops. She completes each dress in five to ten days and saves her income and uses it on need. She is married to M. A. who is a blacksmith and makes iron rods and iron chains. He has been doing this business for the past five years. She is applying for a loan to buy iron for her husband’s blacksmith business.

loans.use: To buy iron for her husband to make iron items to sell

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en: K. Shuhrat is 29 years old, is married and with his wife they are blessed with three children. Shuhrat makes a living growing vegetables and wheat. In addition, he also raises cattle. This provides extra income for his family. Since Shuhrat lacks financial resources, he is hoping to borrow 3,000 Somoni so that he can purchase additional farm inputs to cultivate his farm and plant wheat. Some of his loan will be used to pay for laborers who will help him plant the crops. The loan will also help to pay for food and snacks to sustain him and his laborers during their work. Shuhrat wants to sustain his farming business and hopefully grow it so he eventually has a hectare (2.5 acres) of farmland to provide for the future of his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for his farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more trees for making timber

loans.name: Muhiddin

texts.en: R. Muhiddin is 55 years old and lives in Istaravshan with his wife and children. He has a small farm which he has managed to cultivate after much effort. He spends the majority of his time on his farm because he is keeping watch over anything that may happen. He has been working in agriculture for ten years. His wife supports him in their household. Muhiddin has two children and his older one helps him with the household expenses. Muhiddin plans on improving his family’s living conditions so that he can offer them a better future. With this loan, he will purchase fertilizers to use on his crops so that he can sell more produce at a higher price. loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for his farm

loans.name: Nargis Muhammad Yaqoob Group

texts.en:
Shabana baji wants a loan to buy vehicle wheels to sell.

Yasmeen baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones to sell.

Allah rakhi baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business.

Another Allah rakhi baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine.

Nargis baji is the group leader of these aforementioned ladies. They all belong to a city named Lahore, Pakistan, which is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. They all are very responsible ladies. Nargis baji is very happy to keep them in her group because of their good nature and behavior.

Nargis baji operates a clothes-sewing business because, in Pakistan, for parents to afford their children’s education expenses, they learn some skills; and sewing clothes is one of them. Nargis baji uses her income as needed.

Nargis baji’s husband is M. Y. who runs a game shop in the community. Kids come to his shop to play games. The snooker game is especially popular with children. She is applying for a loan to buy another snooker table for her husband’s game shop.

loans.use: To buy another snooker table for her husband's game shop

loans.name: Mehrikhon

texts.en: A. Mehrikhon is 58 is years old, is married, and is the mother of five children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Mehrikhon is doing all the best to ensure the best future for her children. That is the reason that she has been running her own small business for sixteen years already. She has a grocery store for selling foodstuffs such as sweets (candies), macaroni, soil, sugar, spice and other items. She works from 8:00 a.m. till 5:00 p.m. The business is stable and that allows her to improve the level of the living conditions of her family. Now Mehrikhon needs a loan to increase the range of her selling goods and she requests 5,000 Somoni. Mehrikhon and her children are sincerely grateful for your support. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase her stock of goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock of shoes in bulk

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
G. Firuza sells groceries such as tinned products, sweets, soft drinks, and others. She is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a businessman. Firuza has been selling groceries since 2001. She is responsible for paying for food for the family and the payment of their utility bills. Her loan will be used to increase her grocery inventory in her store. Firuza hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest in a building project she has started with her husband.

Tajikistan:
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, New West culture, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON International:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing stock, purchasing goods for selling

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem S. is a 31-year-old married woman, a mother blessed with two children who are teenagers and in school. She owns a wheelbarrow which she uses to sell frying noodles door-to-door around the village. Her husband, Kom Sim, age 34, works selling clothes by mobile transportation. Because the business of selling clothing is a very profitable one for a whole family, Sem S. would like a loan of $1200 to order additional clothing for her husband to sell. This will provide them with income to attain a comfortable standard of living.

loans.use: To order additional clothing for her husband to sell

loans.name: Khairijon

texts.en:
K. Khairijon, as she is very caringly called by her clients, is the mother of 3 children. Her husband decided to leave them some years ago and he left them with few economic protections. However, this fact did not become a motive for Khairijon to cave in emotionally and spiritually. A little while after she decided to dedicate herself, in an ambulatory way, to selling foodstuffs and opened her grocery store near her house.

Due to the large demand for her typical foodstuffs, she wishes to open a café in the future which will offer better and more comfortable service to the population and increase the quantity of clients. All this would allow her to generate a larger economic income for her family with the aim to elevate their quality of life and education.

In order to carry this out, she is proposing to solicit a loan of 5000 Somoni that will be invested in purchasing more foodstuffs for her grocery. With your help Khairijon will be able to open her café someday and turn her wishes into reality. loans.use: Increasing of stock and purchasing goods for selling

loans.name: Nasreen Muhammad Ishaq Group

texts.en:
Abida baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her dairy business. 

Nasreen baji is a widow and has been a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. Her husband died in an accident. Nasreen baji became unstable after the death of her husband but she plucked up her courage for her kids, two sons and one daughter. She started a business sewing clothes for her kids so that they can continue their studies. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine so that she gets more orders and completes them on time. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cloth and dye for making batick.

loans.name: Farrukh

texts.en: T. Farrukh has a minivan with which he provides transportation services. Having attended to this business for four years, he has gained a rich experience. Initially he rented a car, but in time, after making certain savings, he bought his own minivan. The business is stable and generates the main, considerable income for Farrukh’s family allowing an improvement in living conditions. Currently his minivan needs some repairs. That’s why he needs a loan of 2,500 Somoni to purchase the spare parts. Farrukh thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan with accuracy. The well-being of this family is in your hands. loans.use: To purchase needed spare parts to repair his minivan

loans.name: Zahida Jamil Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Jamila baji and Fozia sultana baji each want a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Rasheedan baji wants a loan to buy creams and cosmetics for her beauty salon.

Munawar baji wants a loan to buy shoes to sell.

My name is Zahida and I have lived in Lahore, Pakistan for the past 12 years.My husband's name is J. A.. He buys clothes from the famous bazaars of Lahore (Ichra and Shahalmi) and sells to the community. He has 3 years of experience in this business. I also operate my own business sewing clothes. My work gives me strength to improve our circumstances. I have been doing this work for the last 2 years. During this time, I have felt a great change that I have become more responsible. I am applying for a loan to buy clothes to expand my husband’s business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional phone accessories and phone credits.

loans.name: Samina Muhammad Arshad Group

texts.en:
Farzana baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell.

Bushra baji and Sadia parveen baji each want a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Hamidan baji wants a loan to buy garments to sell.

Samina baji is a wife of M. A. and has lived in Lahore, Pakistan for the past 8 years. Lahore is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. Samina baji is a very hard-working woman. She cares her family more than herself. She prepares embroidered dresses, which she sells to clothing shops to earn income. She saves her money in a committee and plans to utilize it in her husband’s business when she gets the right amount. Her husband has run a grocery shop in the community for the past 2 years, and Samina baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her husband's grocery shop

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim M., 42, is a good mother who has been blessed with four children: two of whom are married and the others are single and in school.

Sim M. makes a living by buying and selling used goods for a profit. She owns an old motorbike and uses it to transport used goods that she buys from door-to-door in her community. Her husband has always been a civil servant officer but has been retired for a year. Sim M. wants to encourage her husband to have a business to invest in. She would like a $500 loan as capital for her husband to begin selling grocery items out of their home.

loans.use: For her husband to begin selling grocery items out of their home

loans.name: Nasreen Muhammad Bashir Group

texts.en:
Shazia baji and Shamim baji and Samina baji each want a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and clothes) for their decorative embroidering businesses. Rukhsana baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

Nasreen baji is a wife of M. B. who has lived in a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Lahore city is famous for its historic places and for its Punjabi foods. Her husband has dealt in seasonal fruits for the past 2 years. He buys fruits at wholesale and sells to the fruits shops. Nasreen baji is a very caring lady. She takes care of her husband’s every desire and always tries to give him happiness. She packs the fruits before his asking which impresses her husband a lot. She is applying for a loan to grow her husband’s seasonal fruit selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: “Shazia baji is displaying her embroidered cloth in this picture”.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase hair products and wigs in bulk

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu D. is from the village of Balide, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 30 years old. Marichu is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marichu owns & operates a business providing photocopying services in the local community. Marichu has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marichu joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Marichu has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase equipment to improve the business. Marichu is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP to be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Marichu from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay school tuition and to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand photocopy business.

loans.name: Safina's Group

texts.en: N. Safina is the leader of Bunawona group in Kayunga. She is a businesswoman with a business selling used clothes at daily markets in and around Kayunga and Jinja. She sells ladies gomesi (the official dress for women in Uganda), bitenge (a dress using a particular fabric) and other casual dresses plus children’s wear. She has been obtaining loans for eleven years and has been able to pay school fees for her children all this while as she boosts her clothing business with more capital.
