She needs a new loan to help with buying more clothes for sale as well as paying school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell and to pay school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase additional stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
N. Mariam is the leader of Bunawona group in Kayunga. She is a farmer and a business lady dealing in buying farm produce from fellow farmers and taking it for sale in Lugazi Kinyoro. Her produce includes cabbage, egg plants, onions, tomatoes etc. and she always tops this up with her own products from her farm to be able to make some sound profits.

She has had this business for 4 months but before, she had a retail shop and when she transferred, she failed to find another room for rent, hence she resorted to the produce selling business which she can conduct from her home.

She is a single mother of 9 children, all in school, and she cares for 3 dependents with 1 of them in school. The loans have helped her in paying school fees and taking good care of her children. She hopes that one day she will stop borrowing after she has had enough savings and more capital for her business to stand on its own. (Seated at the front is Dianah, the Credit officer for the group)

loans.use: Buying more produce to sell and paying school fees for her children.

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Mrs. Sen M., 29, is married to El Eyseur, who is 33. Since early 2004, she and her husband have had a job as fish sellers. They always wake up quickly every night to buy fish in bulk on credit at the wholesale market and they rush to bring their fishes to sell in the retail market.

This modest couple has been blessed with three children who are teenagers. Presently, the family have hired a store to run their business. Right now, they hope to own a small shop in the market by using a loan from Kiva. This will allow them to cut down this hiring cost. They will use the remainder of the loan to repair their house.

loans.use: To purchase a store in the market and for home repair

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene A. sells sarongs. She is married with 7 children and she is 56 years old. She hopes for the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian Naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy sarongs for resale

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia M. is from the village of Poblacion, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old. Virginia is widowed and has 10 adult-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns & operates a business venture in the construction sector selling lumber. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling lumber to local businesses and community members. Virginia has been engaged in this business for over 7 years and earns approximately 20,000 Philippine Pesos (about $416 US) a month from these activities.

In 2008, Virginia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 pesos from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase tools & other equipment to expand the business. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Virginia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stocks of drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en: Merlinda B. is from the village of Zone 1, Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 42 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Merlinda owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling a variety of goods in the local community such as pre-packed dairy products, snack foods and candies. She also sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Merlinda has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Merlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Merlinda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family and to pay for the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Zone 1, Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Saroum

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroum H. is a villager in Kork Trop village in Kandal province. She is a hardworking, 47-year-old widow with two children who are employed in a garment factory.

Since her children’s work place is far from the house, they usually pay a lot of money for a motorbike taxi drive to work. Thus, Mrs. Saroum H. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her children to drive to work and thus reduce her family expenses.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to drive to work

loans.name: Nasreen Ghulam Nabi Group

texts.en:
Shazia baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell.

Naseem baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business.

Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business.

Rashida baji wants a loan to buy a movie camera for her movie making business. 

Nasreen baji, wife of G. N., lives in Lahore, Pakistan, a city famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. Her husband is a cobbler by profession. He takes orders from the shoe companies and completes their orders by making shoes and earns income. He has been doing this business professionally for the past three years but has been learning this art since his childhood. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy material (leather, nails, and gum) for her husband’s shoe making business.

loans.use: To buy materials for her husband's shoe-making business

loans.name: Mwasiti

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Mwasiti L. from Mbeya who is divorced with four children between the ages of 13 and 29. She has been running a crops business since 1995, purchasing and selling crops. She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week and currently earns about $60 a month. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase crops in bulk for her business. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Mwasiti thanks you for your support! ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for her business

loans.name: William

texts.fr: William A. est âgé de 28 ans, mariés et père d’un enfant. il est conducteur de taxi moto à Lomé, la capitale du Togo. Il exerce ce métier depuis trois ans. William désire avec ce crédit acheter une nouvelle et bailler la première à une autre personne contre des redevances mensuelles.
texts.en:
William A. is 28 years old, maried, and the father of one child. He drives a taxi-moto (i.e. a motorcycle taxi) in Lomé, the capital city of Togo. He has done this job for three years. With this credit, William wishes to buy a new motorcycle and lease the first one to another person for monthly payments.

Translated from French by Laura Buhler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase items  for her beauty salon

loans.name: Fatuma's Group

texts.en:
N. Fatuma has been able to pay back her previous loan on time because she was able to put it to good use once she received it. She is a businesswoman with a tailoring business where she makes dresses, skirts, blouses as well as mending those that are already made. She is married with three children and is also caring for two relatives with full responsibility for their welfare.

Fatuma’s weekly income has increased over time, though her business booms mostly during the festive seasons when everyone is in the mood for buying new clothes. She is also a farmer with plantations and cows that all bring in an income. She needs a loan to be able to buy more clothing materials for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials for her business expansion

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock of chick-feed in bulk

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora S., from the village of Pigsag-an, Cagayan de Oro City, is a 34-year-old married mother of three school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a tailoring business whose main source of income comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials, Leonora is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her third from HSPFI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income for the family and to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate A. sells sarongs and jewelry. She is married with seven children and is 53 years old. She hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man S. was born in 1952 and blessed with six children, all single, two of whom are employed in the garment industry. Man S. is a local tailor, sewing the neighbors' clothes in the village. She also sews a small piece of clothing to produce some furniture to sell for income. In addition, her husband works driving a motor taxi. Man S. will be used the Kiva's loan for capital to purchase additional piece of clothing to make furniture to sell for addition revenue to better meet her family's food needs more adequately. She hopes to use the rest of the loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: To purchase additional piece of clothing

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence retails planks to her customers. She is married with six children and she is 37 years old. She hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en:
N. Joyce is the leader of Kewerimidde group in Lugazi, Katosi. She is a farmer with various food plantations like cassava, matooke (plantain), sweet potatoes and ginger for both home consumption and for sale, as well as having friesian cows at home that give her milk for sale. Joyce also manages her late husband’s fleet of boats that are used for fishing and here she employs men who work on each one of them for pay depending on their day’s catch.

Joyce is a widow with ten children and her loans have helped in boosting her many businesses, giving her children a chance to attain an education. Joyce needs a loan to help with paying school fees and employing labor on her farm for fast and high-quality yields.

loans.use: To pay school fees and to employ manpower on her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk for her business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca sells planks. She is married with six children and she is 53 years old. She hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Elvania's Group

texts.en:
W. Elvania has been able to repay back her previous loan with a lot of ease since it benefitted her business. She sells petrol from a pump in Katosi and, as a result, all her children have attained the best education and she is now educating her grand children and other dependents.

Elvania’s customers are those that live in Kaatosi, mostly taxi drivers and boats, and she is happy that her business is working for her. She is also a farmer using mostly labor on her farm since she is old now and can not afford to work as hard as before. She needs to stock more petrol once she obtains her new loan, so as to make some more profits.

loans.use: To buy more petrol  to sell in her pump

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: Kossi A. est un exploitant de carrière de sable dans les banlieues de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Agé de 45 ans, Kossi est marié et père de 4 enfants. il souhaite avec ce crédit accroître la capacité de son activité en achetant des outils de travail et aussi engager des ouvriers. Kossi compte sur cette chance pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Kossi A.’s business is the exploitation and development of sand (quarrying) in the suburbs of Lomé, the capital city of Togo. At 45 years old, Kossi is married and the father of 4 children. With his credit, he wishes to increase the capacity of his business by purchasing some work tools and also hiring some workers. Kossi is counting on this chance to improve living conditions for his family.

Translated from French by Laura Buhler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing work tools and also hiring some workers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building poles in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase three baskets of mangoes, one basket of papayas, two sacs of pineapples, five clusters of bananas, and two baskets of avocados.

loans.name: Sika

texts.fr: Sika A. est une jeune femme de 29 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est propriétaire d’une pharmacie à Lomé. Sika tient ce commerce depuis 3 ans. Avec ce crédit, Sika souhaite approvisionner son magasin afin de mieux répondre aux besoins de la clientèle sans cesse croissante.
texts.en:
Sika A. is a young woman, 29 years old, married, and the mother of two. She is the owner of a pharmacy in Lomé. Sika has had this business for three years. With this loan, she would like to stock her store in order to respond better to her ever-growing number of customers

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her pharmacy

loans.name: Angèle

texts.fr: A. Angèle est née vers 1981 à Sèdjè dans le Département de l'Ouémé.  Angèle est mariée et mère d’un seul enfant et cet enfant va déjà à l’école. Angèle habite depuis sept ans Fifadji, un quartier de la ville de Cotonou, Capitale Economique de la République du Bénin. Il y a cinq ans que Angèle a commencé à faire le commerce de riz et de  l'huile végétale.  Angèle vend le riz et l’huile végétale en sac de 50Kg et en détaille et l’huile en bidon de 25 litres et en bouteille d’un litre.  Angèle s’approvisionne en riz et en huile végétal chez les fournisseurs de Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin ; parfois à crédit. C’est les sacs de riz de 50Kg et les bidons d’huile de 25 litres que Angèle achète. N’ayant pas suffisamment de moyens  financiers  pour satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Angèle est obligée de prendre une partie de ses produits à crédit. Pour parer à cet état de chose, Angèle s’est adressée à ALIDé pour avoir de prêt. Angèle a déjà eu un prêt de ALIDé. C’est la deuxième demande de prêt que Angèle vient de faire auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Angèle was born around 1981 in Sèdjè in Ouémé county. She is married and the mother of a lone child, who is already going to school. For seven years, Angèle has been living in Fifadji, a district of the city of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Angèle started working in commerce five years ago selling rice and vegetable oil. She sells rice in 50-kg sacks at the retail level, and she sells vegetable oil in 25-liter drums and in one-liter bottles. She stocks up through suppliers of Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin; sometimes on credit. What she buys are these 25-kg sacks of rice and 25-liter drums of oil. Lacking sufficient financial means to satisfy customer demand, she has to take some of her goods on credit. To deal with this situation, she inquired with Alidé to obtain a loan. She has already had an Alidé loan. This in the second loan that she has just gotten from Alidé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seven 50-kg sacks of rice and five 25-L drums of vegetable oil

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase chicks

loans.name: Amewossina

texts.fr: Amewossina A. est une femme de 50 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. elle est commerçante de fruits et légumes à Lomé. Elle souhaite avec ce crédit augmenter la taille de son commerce. Son ambition est d’aller payer les marchandises auprès des agriculteurs et de venir les revendre aux détaillants en ville.
texts.en:
Amewossina A. is a 50-year-old woman, married, and the mother of four. She is a merchant of fruit and vegetables in Lomé. She would like to use this loan to expand her commerce. Her ambition is to go and buy merchandise from growers and to come back and resell them to retailers in town.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetrables for resale

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Mariée  à un monsieur qui exerce dans la mécanique et mère de 02 enfants qui font tous l’école primaire, cette femme pour contribuer aux dépenses de sa famille a commencé en 2006 le commerce de céréales. Ce commerce lui réussit bien car elle réalise de grosses recettes tous les jours. La demande actuelle de ses clients est élevée, elle veut alors augmenter son stock par l’achat de 7 sacs de maïs, 7 sacs d’haricots, 05 sacs de mil et d’autres céréales.
texts.en:
This woman, who is married to a gentleman working in the mechanics field, is the mother of two children who are both in primary school. To help cover family expenses, she began commerce in grains in 2006. This business is successful for her because of hefty receipts each day. The current customer demand is high, so she wants to augment her inventory by buying seven sacks of corn, seven sacks of beans, five sacks of millet, and other grains.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain

loans.name: Armelle

texts.fr: B. Armelle est née le 05/01/1980 à Cotonou, Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin. Armelle est mariée à EWASSADJA Florent.  Armelle est mère de (3)  enfants tous scolarisés. Armelle a fait des études secondaires qu’elle a vite abandonnées au profit d’une formation d'opératrice de saisie. Armelle a été donc opératrice de saisie dans une société de la place pendant cinq ans avant de s'adonner au petit commerce. Armelle habite avec sa famille DEKOUNGBE, un quartier périphérique de Cotonou. C’est à  DEKOUNGBE à son domicile que Armelle mène son activité de vente de divers  (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, charbon de bois, cartes de recharge téléphonique, etc.).  Armelle a également une cabine téléphonique qu’elle gère ; toujours à son domicile. Armelle a déjà eu deux crédits de ALIDé. Pour amener son commerce à un niveau supérieur et mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, Armelle sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
B. Armelle was born on January 5, 1980 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to EWASSADJA Florent and is the mother of three children, all in school. Armelle has studied at the secondary level but soon dropped out in favor of training in data entry. She has thus been a data entry operator in a local company for five years, and then she devoted all her time to a small business. Armelle lives with her family in an outlying district of Cotonou called DEKOUNGBE, here in her home where she does business selling various items: candies, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardine, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, charcoal, phone recharge cards, etc. She also has a phone booth that she manages in her home as well. Armelle has had two Alidé loans before. To bring her business to a higher level and to respond better to customer demand, she’s requesting a third loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 500-mg boxes of pasta, four boxes of laundry soap, two boxes of canned milk and of tomatoes, as well as some telephone recharge cards.

loans.name: Math

texts.en: Math S., 44, has been selling groceries for more than five years, a skill she learned from a friend many years ago. She is now married with five children, all of whom are school-aged. Her husband owns a truck and uses it to transport soil to sell. Math S. is applying for a $1200 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL; she will use half to buy additional grocery inventory to sell and the rest to repair a truck that has broken.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery inventory to sell.

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
N. Phally, 38, has been involved in a grocery business for nine years in PhN. Penh City, with an income of $10 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, with a daily income of $5, who usually stays at a nearby market to provide transportation services to his customers. Together they have three children: two of them are at school, and another one is a phone repairman.

Phally is really satisfied with her grocery business because she can earn a fair income to make a good living. So she has made up her mind to borrow $1,000 from Kiva to expand her inventory of goods in her grocery business. She hopes her two children will be able to finish their high school and study at a good university.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Essohanam

texts.fr: Avant ce monsieur était un agent commercial, mais étant marié et père de famille. Le revenu de sa profession ne lui permettait pas de couvrir toutes les charges de sa famille, il a alors démissionné pour se lancer dans le commerce de produits laitiers FANMILK. Il s’approvisionne auprès de la société FANMILK. Son congélateur  est en panne ce qui a entraîné un baisse considérable de son chiffre d’affaire, il veut acheter  un nouveau congélateur pour rehausser ses ventes, il demande à WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter un congélateur, il est marié et père de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This gentleman, who used to be a commercial agent, is married and the father of a family. The revenues from his profession did not allow him to support his family entirely. So he resigned his job in order to get started in the commerce of FANMILK milk products. He supplies himself through the FANMILK company. His freezer is out of order, resulting in a considerable drop in his sales figures. He wants to buy a new freezer to increase his sales. He’s asking WAGES for his first loan to buy a freezer. He is married and the father of two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a freezer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making chapatis and buns

loans.name: Fazira's Group

texts.en:
N. Fazira is the chairperson of Twesige group in Kayunga. She is happy that she has been able to make a complete repayment of her previous loan having made some good profits after investing in her business. She is a married woman with five children all in school as well as caring for two relatives, one of them an orphan.

She is a farmer with plantations, a poultry farm of egg-laying chickens, plus having cows that give her milk for sale. She is able to manage all her businesses with the help of loans and expects to use this loan to buy more chicken-feed for her chicks and to employ manpower on her farm.

loans.use: To buy more chicken-feed for her chicks and to employ manpower on her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more used-clothes in bulk

loans.name: Afi Delphine

texts.fr: Cette femme vit avec son mari et ses 2 enfants dans le quartier de kégué qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de lomé. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de  poissons frais et d’huile. Une bonne partie de sa clientèle sont propriétaire de restaurant, ils achètent chez elle les poissons  pour leur activité de restauration. Le stock dont elle dispose actuellement ne lui permet de satisfaire ses clients, elle demande alors à WAGES un crédit pour acheter 30 paniers de poissons et 8 bidons d’huile.
texts.en:
This lady lives with her husband and their two children in the Kégué district, which is an outlying neighborhood of the town of Lomé. She sells fresh fish and oil to earn a living. A good number of her customers are owners of restaurants. They buy fish from her for their restaurants.

Her present stock does not allow her to satisfy her clientele's needs, so she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 30 baskets of fish and 8 jerry cans of oil.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fish and oil for re-sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase commodities in bulk for her store.

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de boissons locales alcoolisées appelé "sodabi" , elle fait ce commerce depuis 1994 ce qui lui a donné une parfaite maîtrise de ce commerce. elle fait face actuellement à une rupture de stock c’est pour cela qu’elle s’adresse à WAGES pour solliciter son premier crédit pour acheter  10 bidons de 25 litres de sodabi.
texts.en:
This lady sells a locally-made alcoholic beverage called "sodabi". She has been running this business since 1994 so she is very good at it. She presently is experiencing difficulty keeping her stock up, so she has come to WAGES to request her first loan to buy 10 jerry cans of 25 liters of "sodabi".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing a locally made alcoholic beverage for resale

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina sells sarongs in various colours. She has been in this business for a long time. She is married with three children and she is 40 years old. She hopes for a loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Li

texts.en: The strict-face person shown in the picture is S., age 34, who lives in Phnom Penh. She usually buys fish in bulk on credit at the cheapest price from her wholesale supplier and then sells at retail in the local market to gain a profit. She normally uses a motorbike to supply her investment. From her business, she typically makes around $4 income each day to manage her family's daily expenses more sufficiently. To help meet the family's demands a little more, her husband works in construction. This couple resides with their three young children who are of school-age. S.'s investment has also been interrupted because her motorbike often breaks down. Because of this problem, S. has decided to seek a loan to repair her old motorbike and to use as capital in her selling-fish business.

loans.use: To repair her motorbike and to use as capital

loans.name: Ama Amétowayona

texts.fr: Cette jeune femme a très tôt abandonné les études, devant subvenir à ses propres besoins, elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de produits alimentaires dans le quartier de hedzranawoé, beaucoup de ses clients apprécient ses services. Sa clientèle grandit elle voudrait mieux les accueillir et sollicite pour le faire de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter  4 sacs de riz , 2 sacs de gari, des huiles "NIOTO" et divers produits alimentaires
texts.en:
This young woman left school early on. Since she had to support herself, she went into selling foodstuffs in the Hedzranawoé neighborhood; many of her customers are grateful for her service. Her clientele is growing and she would like to welcome them all, so she is asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 4 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of "gari" (manioc grits), NIOTO brand oils, and various other foodstuffs.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs for re-sale

loans.name: John's Group

texts.en:
K. John is happy to be asking for another loan today after, together with his fellow group members, completing the repayment of his previous loan.

John is a hardworking man and a taxi driver on the Kampala- Bugerere highway, taking passengers to and fro. He is happy that the loans have made his taxi work well, enabling him to repair it whenever need arises. He has been able to buy land from it, has bought cows that give him milk and he also has farms for agriculture where he is able to produce food for sale and home consumption.

John needs a new loan to help with paying school fees for his six children and to employ workers to help his wife with the farm work.

loans.use: To pay for manpower on his farm and to pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Bedzrah

texts.fr: Bedzrah K. est un jeune homme de 27 ans, marié et père d’un petit garçon. Il est tailleur depuis 3 ans à Lomé. Bedzrah souhaite avec ce crédit améliorer les ses prestations pour mieux servir sa clientèle. Elle désire acheter deux machine à coudre ; en plus il souhaite exercer le commerce des tissus ce qui permettra à ses clients la facilité dans le choix des tissus à confectionner.
texts.en:
Bedzrah K. is a young man of 27, married and the father of a little boy. He has been a tailor for three years in Lomé. Bedzrah hopes to use this loan to improve his services so that he can better satisfy his clientele. He wants to buy two sewing machines. Moreover, he wants to go into selling cloth which will make it easier for his clients to choose the fabrics they want to have made up.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing 2 sewing machines and cloth for resale

loans.name: Kokouvi

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur a appris le métier de la soudure, en 2004 il s’est mis à son propre compte et a ouvert un atelier. Il fabrique des portes et des fourres qu’il vend à ses clients. Il expose sa marchandise devant son atelier pour attirer les clients. Les matières nécessaires à son activité étant épuisées, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter des tôles et diverses matières.
Il est marié et père de 02 enfants, c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman learned welding, and in 2004 he went out on his own and opened a workshop. He makes doors etc. that he sells to his customers. He displays his merchandise in front of his workshop so as to attract customers. He is presently out of the raw materials he needs to make his products, so he is asking WAGES for his first loan to buy corrugated iron and various other materials.

He is married and the father of 2 children. He supports his family with the revenue from his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of raw materials for making doors, etc.

loans.name: Justine

texts.fr:
S. Justine est née le 01/01/1960 à Adjara dans le Département de l'Ouémé. Justine est mère de cinq (5) enfants dont quatre (4) sont scolarisés. Justine
 vend des produits vivriers (maïs, haricot, farine de manioc, etc.), de bois de chauffage et de la friperie. Justine vend les friperies au marché de Cococodji non loin de Cotonou,  Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin. Mais c’est à domicile que  Justine vend le bois de chauffage et les produits vivriers. Justine a déjà bénéficié de deux de ALIDé; crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener ses activités à un stade supérieur. Pour renforcer son fonds de roulement dans l'optique de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Justine  sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Justine was born on January 1, 1960 in Adjara in the Department of Ouémé. She is the mother of 5 children, of whom 4 are enrolled in school. Justine sells foodstuffs (maize, dried beans, manioc flour), firewood and used clothing. She sells the used clothing in the Cococodji market, not far from Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. But she sells the firewood and the foodstuffs out of her home.

Justine has already received two loans from ALIDé, which she correctly reimbursed and which allowed her to bring her business to the next level. To bolster her working capital so as to better satisfy her clientele, Justine is requesting a 3rd loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a truckload of firewood and a half-bale of used clothing

loans.name: François

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un jeune célibataire très dynamique qui exerce comme activité la vente de pièces détachées, c’est avec le revenu de cette activité qu’il subvient  à ses besoins, il a commencé ce commerce depuis 2007, il s’approvisionne au marché local du port autonome de lomé. Son stock de pièces détachées est épuisé, il veut rehausser son stock et sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour se réapprovisionner en pièces détachées.
texts.en:
This gentleman is a young, single man, very energetic, who sells spare parts. The income from this business is what he uses to support himself. He began this business in 2007 and buys his stock at the local market of the autonomous pot of Lomé. His stock of spare parts is presently expended, so he needs to replenish it and has asked WAGES for his first loan to stock up on spare parts.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of spare parts for re-sale

loans.name: Yedunam

texts.fr: Yedunam B. est une femme de 30 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. elle détient un bar dans un quartier populaire de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. elle opère dans ce secteur de puis 4 ans. Avec ce premier crédit de FECECAV, elle souhaite aménager son bar afin de donner un cadre plus accueillant à sa clientèle. Ceci fera accroître ses recettes et par ricochet une amélioration de ses conditions de vie.
texts.en:
Yedunam B., 30, is married and the mother of 2 children. She keeps a bar in a working class neighborhood of Lomé, the capital of Togo. She has been in this sector for 4 years. With her first loan from FECECAV, she hopes to refurbish her bar so that it will be a more welcoming atmosphere for her clientele. This should increase her sales and thus lead to an improvement in her living conditions.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: refurbish her bar and add to her inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stocks of clothes in bulk for her store

loans.name: Danialou

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un tailleur, il vend aussi des bazins et confectionne aussi avec ses bazins des habits qu’il vend à ses clients, il fait cette activité depuis 2005, il est célibataire et c’est avec le revenu de son activité qu’il subvient à ses charges et aide financièrement certains de ses frères et sœurs. La demande de ses clients dépasse ce qu’il peut offrir. Pour pouvoir les satisfaire convenablement il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des tissus bazins. Il est célibataire et subvient à ses charges grâce aux revenus de son activité.
texts.en:
This gentleman is a tailor, but he also sells "bazin" (a sort of damask cloth) and sews clothes out of his "bazins" that he sells to his clients. He has been in this sector since 2005; he is single and it is with the income from this business that he supports himself, as well as helping out some of his brothers and sisters financially. The demand from his clientele is greater than he can keep up with, so to satisfy their needs appropriately, he is asking WAGES for a loan that will allow him to buy "bazin" cloth. He is single and supports himself thanks to the income from this business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "bazin" cloth

loans.name: Tumruu

texts.en:
Tumruu D. is a married woman who, together with her husband, Erdenehuu, lives in a "ger" (nomadic housing tent) district on the plot of land they own in Arhangay, one of Mongolian central provinces. All her children are living apart with their own families.

Since 2006, with her sibling, Tumruu has been running a dry-cleaning service in a rental place. When she began running her business, her working capital was 5.5 million tugrug (1 USD = 1,100 MNT in 2006). During the last three years of hard work, her capital has increased by 2 million MNT. Tumruu's husband helps his spouse's business if he has time.

During the interview with credit staff Tumruu says that her wish is to have her own place to run her business, since paying a rent fee every month is tough. With this loan she plans to buy new equipment and raw materials for her dry-cleaning business.

loans.use: To buy equipment and raw materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cloth and other accessories for her business

loans.name: Abdusattor

texts.en: Y. Abdusattor is 39 years old and lives with his wife and four children. Abdusattor is an animal farmer. He owns cows and sells their milk with the help of his wife and elder son. In order to further develop his business, Abdusattor wants to take out a loan to buy one or two more cows and feed for them. After fattening them up, he will be able to sell them at a more favorable price. Then he will be able to use the profit from his business for the well-being of his family. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase one or two more cows and feed for them

loans.name: Pauline's Group

texts.en:
M. Pauline is a very hardworking lady with a retail shop business that has gone through stages to its current state. Using her lending group, she has been getting loans from Pearl Microfinance for fourteen years now and she is happy that she is benefiting from this change. She is able to pay school fees for all her children as well as feeding and clothing them. Her home is now filled with items that have been bought in the process like a sofa set, sideboard, television and so on. Hence, all her family is happy.

Pauline needs a loan to help with restocking her retail shop with more goods as well as paying school fees for her children.

loans.use: To restock her shop and to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mwasiti

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Mwasiti H. from Mwanza. She is married with one child who is 3 years old. Mwasiti has been running a shop business selling mobile-phone accessories since 2006. It is amazing how many people have mobile phones in Tanzania. This is probably attributable to the fact that it is the only form of phone communication available to most people because there are few landlines and because mobile phones are relatively cheap here. 

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, four days per week and is assisted by one employee. Mwasiti currently earns about $150 per month from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase more mobile-phone accessories. In the future, she plans to open another business. Mwasiti thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more mobile-phone accessories

loans.name: Teko

texts.fr: Teko D. est un jeune homme de 37 ans, marié et père de 2 enfants. il est propriétaire d’un pressing. afin d’être plus compétitive sur le marché et offrir à la clientèle un service de qualité, Teko souhaite acheter une machine à laver et d’autres outils de travail. Il espère aussi engager deux employés pour l’aider dans l’accomplissement de ses tâches.
texts.en:
Teko D. is a young man of 37, married and the father of 2 children. He owns a cleaner's. So as to be more competitive in the marketplace while offering his clients quality service, Teko hopes to buy a washing machine and other apparatus for his business. He also hopes to hire two employees to help him get his work done.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase a washing machine and other necessary apparatus

loans.name: Silimanio

texts.en:
Silimano S. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and bread. She is requesting a loan to buy more groundnuts to make paste to sell. Silimano is 30 years old and married to a peasant. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are all delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts to make paste

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase stock of African traditional cloth in bulk

loans.name: Mirsada

texts.en:
Mirsada Dropić was born in 1979 and comes from the suburbs of the town of Živinice. She is married and has one son who is in primary school.

Mirsada’s husband works now outside of Bosnia and Mirsada spent all the savings to provide him with needed documents, paying all the costs related to that. She had to sell two calves to survive the time before her husband got his salary.

Mirsada was already a user of a Kiva loan. She repaid her previous loan on time and is now requesting the new one. Mirsada requested the loan of 1,200 KM from WWI (Žene za Žene International) to buy a young steer. She has enough cattle feed and hopes to earn a good profit from reselling that steer. Mirsada`s wish is to have a food stall.

loans.use: To purchase a young steer

loans.name: Kamiro

texts.en:
Kamiro C., currently in the business of selling various goods in her shop, is requesting a loan to stock more goods to sell.  Thirty-five years old and married to a peasant, she has five children, all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel and lodge.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as  measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more goods to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase additional chicks in bulk.

loans.name: Shamim Aftab Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Shamim baji, the wife of A. A., has lived in the mid-sized city of Riwind, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband has been running a grocery shop in the community for the past five years, his good service garnering many customers. Shamim baji operates a cloth-selling business based upon the orders she receives from her neighbors, saving her income in a committee from which she plans to buy more clothes. Shamim baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries to expand her husband’s grocery shop.

The other members of this group loan are as follows: Safia baji wants a loan to buy bed sheets to sell. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy another motorbike for her bike-rental business. Shahla baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (beads, colored thread and clothes) for preparing decorative embroidered dresses.

The funds in this group loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase stock in bulk for her store

loans.name: Julienne

texts.fr: B. Julienne est née  vers 1979. Julienne est célibataire sans enfant.  C’est dans la maison de son grand-père à Zogbo un quartier de Cotonou, Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin que Julienne vit depuis vingt (20) ans. Julienne a abandonné les cours au secondaire pour se lancer dans le commerce.  Julienne a vendu d'abord les produits cosmétiques. Depuis trois (3) ans maintenant, c’est les œufs que vend Julienne. Julienne a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit de ALIDé et a bien remboursé ce crédit. Actuellement, Julienne sollicite un second prêt de ALIDé pour accroître le niveau de son activité et relancer la vente de produits cosmétiques.
texts.en:
B. Julienne was born around 1979. She is unmarried and has no children. She has been living for 20 years in her grandfather’s house in Zogbo, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She dropped out of secondary school in order to get started in commerce. First, she sold cosmetics. For three years now, she has been selling eggs. Julienne has already benefited from an Alidé loan and has repaid it. Currently, she’s requesting a second Alidé loan to increase her level of business and to restart her cosmetics sales.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy thirty trays of eggs and some cosmetics products (bath soap, creams, and body lotions)

loans.name: Najma Muhammad Hussain Khan Group

texts.en:
Seema baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell.

Reshma baji wants a loan to buy material (leather and nails) for her shoe-making and selling business.

Irshad baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Saima Nazir baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business.

Najma baji is the wife of M. H. K. who has been a citizen of a mid-size city named Riwind, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Her husband runs a dairy business. He gets milk from his buffalo and sells its milk to the milk shops and in the community.

Najma baji operates a business sewing clothes to save money for a rainy day. She is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies also. Her members are very happy to have her as a leader. She is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to increase the profit of her husband’s dairy business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for their dairy business

loans.name: Janet's Group

texts.en:
N. Janet is the chairperson of Alinyikira group in Mutundwe. She is a strong business lady with a retail shop for 3 years and a poultry farm for a long time, both businesses she transacts at her home. In the shop, she sells general merchandise and eggs from her chickens while she also keeps broilers and layers interchangeably. She is seeking her 6th year while taking loans with the group, and she hopes to stock her shop with more goods plus buy more feed for her chickens.

Janet is a lucky mother. She has 7 children of whom 5 are graduates at the best university of Makerere while 2 are soon completing their studies at the same university. On top of this, she pays school fees and caters for 4 orphaned nephews in secondary and primary school.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop and buying feed for her poultry farm

loans.name: Safia Abdul Ghaffar Group

texts.en:
Muniran baji and Naseem baji and Khursheed baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

Shaista baji wants a loan to buy a power loom.

Safia baji is the wife of A. G. who has been living in a mid-sized city named Riwind, Pakistan for the past 18 years. Her husband runs a dairy business in the community. He gets milk from the buffalo which he has in his house. She also helps him by milking them. She is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to grow her husband’s dairy business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for their dairy business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Esther M. from Mwanza. She is married with a child 1 year old. Esther has been running a shop since 2008, selling water, soda, eggs, soap, and biscuits. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week,and is assisted by one employee.

Esther currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more eggs, some drinks such as sodas, sugar, and rice. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Esther thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs, some drinks, sugar, and rice for resale

loans.name: Mahsudchon

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

 Махсудчон Чабборов занимается торговлей. Он продает женскую обувь. В самом начале предпринимательской деятельности Махсудчон сам привозил товар из Китая и продовал его на рынке города.Сейчас он покупает товар у поставщиков. С 14 лет он помогал своей матери на рынке, которая так же продовала обувь. Теперь, он имея достаточный опыт работы в сфере торговли, сам справляется с этой работой. 
 Хочет получить кредит для закупа обуви летнего сезона, а так же расширить ассортимент своего товара. Для достижения этой цели, Махсудчон запрашивает сумму в размере 1600 сомони
texts.en:
Mahsudchon C. is involved in sales of women’s shoes. At the beginning of his entrepreneurship, he brought merchandise from China and sold it at a city market. Now he buys the merchandise from suppliers. Since Mahsudchon was 14 years old, he helped his mother sell shoes at a market. Now that he has plenty of experience in this field, he is able to do the work himself. Mahsudchon wants to obtain this loan in order to purchase a stock of summer season shoes and to expand his goods assortment. Mahsudchon needs a sum of 1600 somoni to achieve this goal.

MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”. “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of summer season shoes

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 29-year-old Flora B. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, 6 and 9 years old. Flora has been running a pharmacy since 2000, selling human medicine such as Panadol and Strepsils. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week.

Flora currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more medicine for her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Flora thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tea, biscuits, cooking oil, and eggs

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: N. Christine est née vers 1964 à Cotonou, Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin. Christine est mariée à Michel ADJAGBE, un pêcheur.  Christine est mère de trois (3) enfants tous scolarisés: Bonaventure, Ulrich et Romuald. Christine et sa famille habitent à Zogbo un quartier de Cotonou. Christine n'est jamais allée à l'école. Depuis son enfance, Christine a été initiée à la vente de crevettes fumées et poissons frais. C’est cette activité que Christine continue d’exercer à ce jour. Christine vend ses produits en gros à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Mais par moment certains des clients de Christine passent chez elle à la maison pour faire leurs achats. Christine a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit de ALIDé  pour son activité et  elle a bien remboursé ce crédit. Christine est satisfaite du premier crédit de ALIDé, elle espère toujours bénéficier des prestations de ALIDé pour consolider son activité. En effet, Christine sollicite son second crédit  de ALIDé pour s'approvisionner davantage en crevettes fraîches.
texts.en:
N. Christine was born around 1964 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married to Michel ADJAGBE, a fisherman, and is the mother of three children, Bonaventure, Ulrich, and Romuald, who are all in school. Christine and her family live in Zogbo, a district of Cotonou. She never went to school. Since her childhood, she has been initiated in selling smoked shrimp and fresh fish. This has been her business to this day. She sells her products wholesale at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. But at times, certain of her customers come by her house to make their purchases. Christine has already benefited from an Alidé loan and is happy with the first loan. She now hopes to benefit from Alidé services to consolidate her business. To this end, she’s requesting her second loan with Alidé for added supplies of fresh shrimp.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 30 baskets of fresh shrimp

loans.name: Stanley

texts.fr: Ce jeune a abandonné les études en 2001, très tôt il s’est lancé dans le commerce de mèches. Il  s’approvisionne au GHANA et au NIGERIA pour pouvoir réaliser une plus grande marge bénéficiaire sur ses ventes. Il vend aux coiffeuses et aux revendeuses de produits cosmétiques. Une partie de son stock étant épuisée, il veut se réapprovisionner et acheter de nouveaux modèles de mèches pour  attirer plus de clients. Il sollicite alors de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 1 carton de mèches « pression funlay », 1 carton de mèches « lovinia AFRO-B » et 1 carton de mèches « NOBLES HONEY MOON ».
texts.en:
This young man dropped out of school in 2001 and soon got started in the commerce of hair extensions. He supplies himself from Ghana and from Nigeria to be able to realize a larger profit margin on his sales. He sells to hairdressers and to cosmetics retailers. A portion of his inventory is out of stock. He wants to stock up again and to buy new styles of hair extensions to attract more customers. He’s therefore requesting his first loan from WAGES to buy hair extensions: a box each of Pression Funlay, Lovinia AFRO-B, and NOBLES HONEY MOON.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hair extensions

loans.name: Madaraka

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Madaraka M. from Mwanza. She is married with four children, between the ages of 19 and 24 years old. Madaraka has been running a shop since 2008, selling sodas, salt, and sugar. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by one employee.

Madaraka currently earns about 150 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase rice, soda, sugar, and beans. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Madaraka thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase rice, soda, sugar, and beans

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Cette  jeune femme est une femme célibataire, elle travaille dur pour pouvoir subvenir à ses besoins quotidiens elle s’est lancée dans le commerce d’appareil d'ustensiles de cuisine.  Elle s’approvisionne au marché  local du port autonome de Lomé. Son stock étant épuisé elle veut se réapprovisionner et ayant déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit, elle sollicite son deuxième crédit pour acheter 4 cuisinières de haute qualité, 2 moulinesse, 4 thermousse 2 cartons de plats et 5 lanternes de WAGES.
texts.en:
This young woman is an unmarried. She works hard to be able to support herself day to day. She got started in the commerce of kitchen utensils and equipment. She stocks up at the local market of the Autonomous Port of Lomé. Being out of stock, she wants to resuppy herself. And having had a WAGES loan, she’s requesting her second loan to buy four high-quality cookers, two moulinesse, four thermousse, two boxes of plates, and five lanterns.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensiles

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr: Komla D. est un homme de 47 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants. il est soudeur depuis plus de 10 ans. Il espère avec ce crédit acheter des tôles et des boîtes à outils pour l’exécution de ses commandes. Cette opportunité lui permettra de gagner plus d’argent pour mieux satisfaire les besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Komla D. is a 47-year-old man, married, and the father of three. He has been a welder for over ten years. He hopes to use this loan to buy sheet metal and toolboxes for carrying out customer orders. This opportunity will enable him to earn more money to meet the needs of his children better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheet metal and toolboxes

loans.name: Mahsudchon

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Махсудчону Султонову 25 лет, но не смотря на его молодость, он уже достаточно хорошо умеет зарабатывать деньги. Махсудчон торгует на рынке мужской обувью. Покупает товар у поставщиков и продает его на рынке. Первый раз Махсудчон кредитовался у нас в январе месяце, ему понравились наши условия кредитования, и он получил хорошую прибыль от продажи обуви, которые приобрел на полученный кредит. Теперь он опдал заявку на получения нового кредита, так как его доход и наш кредит, дают ему возможность разнообразить свой товар. Махсудчон планирует в ассортимент своего товара включить детскую обувь.
Наш клиент женат и ростит дочь.
texts.en:
Mahsudchon S. is 25 years old, but even he is so young he knows well how to make money. Mahsudchon sells mens shoes on the market. The buys the merchandise from suppliers and resells on the market. Mahsudchon has taken out a loan for the first time in January. He liked our loan terms and he received good profit from selling of shoes which he bought using the loan money. Now he has applied for a new loan as his income and the loan let him add variety to his merchandise. Mahsudchon plans to include children's shoes into the assortment of his inventory. Our client is married and raising a daughter.

MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy children's shoes

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Joyce M. from Mwanza. She is married with three children, between the ages of 5 and 16 years old. Joyce has been running a bar since 2008. Her bar is a good place to relax with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. You can relax on a plastic chair under a tree, with a beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to everyone who happens to wander by.

Joyce works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week. She currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase more beer, soda and water. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Joyce thanks you for your support!

ABUOT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. P> One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more beer, soda and water

loans.name: Ayélé

texts.fr:
Cette femme est une infirmière accoucheuse, pour pouvoir aider les malades qui ont peu de moyens de se procurer des médicaments ; elle a entamé la vente de produits génériques. Une partie de son stock est épuisée, elle veut se réapprovisionner et les moyens dont elle dispose étant insuffisant, elle sollicite un autre crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 cartons de quinine, 15 cartons analgin injectable, 5 cartons de « lufanter », 10 boite de « surdex », 16 boîtes de serum glocosé.
Elle est mariée et mère de 01 enfant
texts.en:
This is a woman who is an obstetrics nurse. To help patients who have little money for acquiring medicines, she started selling generic pharmaceutical products. Part of her inventory is exhausted. She wants to stock up again. But since the means at her disposal are insufficient, she’s requesting another loan from WAGES to buy: ten boxes of quinine, fifteen boxes of injectable Analgin (painkiller and fever reducer), five boxes of Lufanter (anti-malarial drug), ten containers of Surdex, and sixteen boxes of glucose serum. She is married and the mother of one child.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell generic pharmaceuticals

loans.name: Johnape

texts.en:
Johnape B. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Johnape is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Johnape owns and operates a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. She is also engaged in the food service business, cooking snack foods and peddling them to her neighbors. Johnape has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Johnape joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Johnape is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as additional working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Johnape from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family and for the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 54-year-old Neema M. from Mbeya. She is married with 6 children, between the ages of 20 and 31. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are orphans. Neema has been running a business since 2009, making and selling baskets.

She works at the business for 9-12 hours per day, 6 days per week. Neema currently earns about 60 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase basket material in bulk. In the future, she plans to open a new business. Neema thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA:

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase basket material in bulk

loans.name: Bobodonkul

texts.ru: Бободонкул Мамадалиев проживает в районе Руми. Возраст 59 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Бободонкул работал более 30 по профессии агрономом. После этого он решил начать свой бизнес. Он более 20 лет занимается земледелием. Бободонкул в основном выращивает картофель, капусту. Получив кредит, он хочет выращивать еще и овощи.
texts.en:
Bobodonkul M. lives in the Rumi region. He is 59 years old. He is married and has six children. Bobodonkul has worked as an agronomist for more than 30 years. After that he decided to start his own business. He has been in agriculture for more than twenty years. Bobodonkul mainly grows potatoes, cabbage. For the received loan he wants to grow more vegetables.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For expansion of business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr:
Ce monsieur fait du commerce en détail, il vend des sachets d’eau « PURE WATER », des vins, des fortifiants et divers autres produits alimentaires. Voulant agrandir son activité et réaliser plus de recettes, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 100 sachets de pure « WATER », 3 bouteilles de vin, 3 cartons de fortifiants, il exerce son activité à proximité du marché local du quartier de Hédzranawoè.
Il est marié et père de 3 enfants, c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who works in retail commerce. He sells bags of “PURE WATER”, wine, tonics, and various other items. Wanting to expand his business and to realize more income, he’s requesting his first loan from WAGES to buy 100 bags of “PURE WATER”, three bottles of “Serpent” wine, and three boxes of tonics. He operates near the local marketplace of Hedzranawoè. He is married and the father of 3 children. With the revenues from his business, he provides for his family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies

loans.name: Gaudensia

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 47-year-old Gaudensia N. from Mwanza. She is married with five children, between the ages of 18 and 25 years old. Gaudensia has been running a shop since 2005, selling biscuits, sodas and water. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week.

Gaudensia currently earns about 200 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to purchase beans, rice and wheat flour. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Gaudensia thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase beans, rice and wheat flour

loans.name: Emobor

texts.en: Emobor sells sarongs of various colours and sorts. She is married with 2 children and she is 31 years old. She hopes for the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget S. sells sarongs. She is married with 4 children and she is 39 years old. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase some grains such as maize and wheat flour for resale

loans.name: Gaydullaev

texts.ru: Гайдуллаев Аловаддин проживает в городе Истаравшане. Занимается продажей различных  красок и стройматериалов для ремонта. Стаж работы в этой сфере деятельности 5 лет. У Аловадина магазин рядом с вещевом рынком, что позволяет ему иметь множество покупателей. Кроме этого Аловаддин вместе со своим отцом занимается евроремонтом домов и квартир. Кредит хочет получить для закупа различных красок и стройматериалов.
texts.en:
A. Gaydullaev lives in the town of Istaravshan. He sells different kinds of paints and building materials for home remodeling. He has five years of experience in this type of work. A.'s store is located next to the clothing market which lets him have many customers. Besides that A. together with his father make European style remodeling of homes and apartments. He wants to get a loan to buy different paints and building materials.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different kinds of paints and building materials

loans.name: Koami

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est marié et père de 2 enfants, l’activité génératrice de revenu qu’il exerce et qui lui permet de subvenir aux charges de sa famille est la couture, il fait ce commerce depuis plus de dix ans, ce qui fait qu’il en a une parfaite maîtrise. Il confectionne aussi des habits qu’il expose pour attirer le regard des passants. Il veut acheter une machine à surfilage, une autre machine à coudre et 1 rouleau de tissus, c’est pour cette raison qu’il demande à WAGES son premier crédit.
texts.en:
